name: Audition Assistant
description: This app is an all in one music practice assistant. It features a multifunctional metronome, practice journal, and audition planner.
tools: Python, Django, React, PostgreSQL, JavaScript, HTML, CSS, Materialize, Heroku, Howler.js, AWS S3, Open Opus API

name: Bat Buster
description: Bat Buster is a browser based arcade style game built with HTML, CSS, and JavaScript. The user uses the mouse and keyboard to move the player character while avoiding and shooting oncoming swarms of bats.

name: Kindr
description: Kindr is a heartwarming app designed to inspire and spread kindness in your community and beyond. With Kindr, you can create and share meaningful good deeds for others to undertake, fostering a culture of compassion and positivity. Users can participate by completing deeds posted by fellow members or by taking on the daily challenge, making each day an opportunity to make the world a better place, one act of kindness at a time.
tools: React, MongoDB/Mongoose, Express, Node.js, HTML, CSS, Auth0, OpenAI API

name: Jaz Tsui Portfolio
description: This website serves as a hub for documentation of the works by Toronto based multimedia artist Jasmine Tsui. Pared down full screen wireframes were designed by Jasmine and provided to me in order to create the website. We collaborated on the design and implementation over two months, leading to this final product. A refactor of the site into a React based SPA is currently in progress

name: Scenic Shenanigans
description: Scenic Shenanigans is a travel planner and journal. Users can add each other to various trips to plan activities and share photos with each other.
tools: Node.js, MongoDB/Mongoose, Express, HTML, CSS, OAuth2, OpenAI API

name: Here and There
description: Here and There by Roger Reynolds. Performed on March 13th, 2020 at Array Space, Toronto

name: All At Once
description: My first album, using no inpput mixer/equalizer, percussion, and various softwares

name: Elemental Suite
description:
The Elemental Suite is a multimedia performance co-created by myself and Jasmine Tsui of Duo Cichorium. It features four movements inspired by natural elements, employing diverse technologies:
Matchbox Ritual: Recycled drawers serve as percussion instruments, equipped with homemade piezo microphones and Arduinos. Max processes the microphone signal, allowing Arduinos to control three lamps for each performer in real-time, creating a dynamic lighting experience.
Morphogenesis: This movement showcases a handmade tree-like sculpture, vividly projected using OBS-based mapping. Each section (roots, trunk, foliage) and the performance space are individually projected upon, enhancing the visual impact.
Desiderium: Homemade hydrophones capture the sounds of water and instruments within it. These sounds are then fed into Ableton Live for amplification and live processing, creating a captivating auditory experience.
Scintillation: The final movement combines the MUGIC motion sensor, Arduino, and Max, enabling performers to control fans directed at wind chimes through gestures while playing percussion. The motion sensor data also influences various sound parameters, adding an interactive element to the performance.

name: Where am I?
description: A collection of pieces using no-input mixer and various electronics. Where am I? attempts to blur the line between performer and instrument, using custom built electronics and biological sensors to incorporate the two into a single entity.

name: Three Roses
description: Three Roses is a quartet for percussion, incorporating 2 technological devices to give the performers control over lighting and sound design. First is the MUGIC, a gestural sensor developed by violinist Mari Kimura, which you can see on each of the players’ hands. Second is the Arduino which controls the lights, and through the software Max MSP can respond to the gestures of the performers captured by the MUGIC. This piece was commissioned by Aiyun Huang for the TaPIR lab in the early stages of COVID, and as such has gone through multiple iterations from live concert performance, to remote collaboration, and eventually settled as an in person recording project.

name: Gymnopedie No. 1
description: Gymnopedia No. 1 by Erik Satie, arranged for glockenspiel and marimba
